questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son because of gradually progressive yellow discoloration of his skin and generalized pruritus for the past 2 weeks. During this period, his appetite has decreased and he has had a 6.5-kg weight loss. He reports that his stool appears pale and his urine is very dark. Three years ago, he had an episode of acute upper abdominal pain that was treated with IV fluids, NSAIDs, and dietary modification. He has stopped drinking alcohol since then; he used to drink 1–2 beers daily for 40 years. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows yellowing of the conjunctivae and skin. The abdomen is soft and non-tender; a soft, cystic mass is palpated in the right upper quadrant. Serum studies show Abdominal ultrasonography shows an anechoic cystic mass in the subhepatic region and dilation of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma This patient presents with painless jaundice, anorexia, and unexplained weight loss. Investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, signs of extrahepatic biliary tract obstruction (dilated intra and extrahepatic bile ducts), and a distended non tender gall bladder (anechoic subhepatic cystic mass). These features, esp. in a person of advanced age with a history of smoking and alcohol consumption, are highly suggestive of a pancreatic adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, obstructing the distal common bile duct.

Highyeild:

Carcinoma Pancreas is a type of cancer that originates in the pancreas, with the most common type being pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The majority of PDAC cases occur in the head of the pancreas, with a smaller percentage occurring in the body and tail. Management: More than 85% of patients with ductal adenocarcinoma have advanced disease and are not suitable for resection. If imaging shows a potentially resectable tumor , surgical resection should be considered as it offers the only chance of a cure, albeit a small one. For patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease , the primary objective should be to relieve symptoms, improve quality of life, and extend survival, rather than achieving a cure. Patients with pancreatic cancer fall into four categories: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced and unresectable, and metastatic. Resectable patients should be offered surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Borderline resectable patients may be offered neoadjuvant chemotherapy with or without chemoradiotherapy, followed by surgical resection if the disease has been downstaged. Adjuvant therapy should follow. Locally advanced and unresectable patient s should be offered systemic chemotherapy , with surgery being a possibility in a small cohort who get downstaged. Metastatic patients should be offered systemic chemotherapy. If a cystic tumor is encountered, regardless of size, surgical resection should be considered as it carries a reasonable chance of cure. Tumors of the ampulla have a good prognosis and should be resected if possible, as should some rare tumors and neuroendocrine lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about gastrinomas?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of gastrinomas are located in the gastrinoma triangle

options.label: B
options.text: 25% of all gastrinomas are associated with MEN 2

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium stimulation tests are used to differentiate gastrinomas from other causes of hypergastrinemia

options.label: D
options.text: Gastrinomas associated with MEN are usually located in the duodenum

questions.correct_answer: B. 25% of all gastrinomas are associated with MEN 2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

25% of all gastrinomas are associated with MEN 2 Gastrinomas are rare gastrin-secreting tumors of non-beta pancreatic islet cells. Most tumors are sporadic and are commonly found in the pancreas. About 25% are associated with MEN type 1 and tend to be found in the duodenum. Sporadic tumors have greater malignant potential. Overall, the majority of the tumors are located in the gastrinoma triangle, which is bounded superiorly by the cystic duct, inferiorly by the second and third parts of the duodenum, and medially by the head of the pancreas.

Highyeild:

In 70-90% of patients, primary gastrinoma is found in Passaro's triangle, but whole-body imaging is required due to the possibility of gastrinomas appearing anywhere in the body. SSTR (octreotide) scintigraphy in combination with CT is the test of choice, and EUS can be helpful in localizing tumors in the pancreatic head or duodenal wall. MEN1 syndrome should be ruled out before surgery, and surgical treatment is justified in patients with sporadic gastrinomas. Approximately 50% of gastrinomas metastasize to lymph nodes or the liver, and patients who meet the criteria for operability should undergo exploration for possible removal of the tumor. Pancreatic tumors are usually larger than tumors arising in the duodenum, and more often they have lymph node metastases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D: All other statements are true

Extraedge:

Despite the lack of success in achieving a biochemical cure, long-term survival rates are good, even in patients with liver metastases. The best results are seen after the complete excision of small sporadic tumors originating in the duodenum, while large tumors associated with liver metastases located outside of Passaro's triangle have the worst prognosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents to his physician with a 4-week history of upper abdominal pain and diarrhea. He also describes a few episodes of ‘dark-colored’ vomitus during this period. The general examination is unremarkable. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals multiple ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrinoma Gastrinomas primarily occur in the pancreas and duodenum and are malignant in nearly two-thirds of cases. The patients may present with upper abdominal pain and vomiting; the vomitus may be ‘coffee-ground’ due to the digestion of blood (from the ulcers) within the stomach. Gastrinomas may either arise sporadically or as part of Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (i.e. peptic ulceration, gastric acid hypersecretion, and islet cell tumors of the pancreas). Sporadic Zollinger–Ellison syndrome occurs most frequently in the fifth decade of life.

Highyeild:

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is caused by gastrinoma , an endocrine tumor that secretes gastrin, leading to acid hypersecretion and peptic ulceration. Patients with ZES may present with abdominal pain, peptic ulcer disease, severe esophagitis, and diarrhea. In the era of effective antacid therapy, the presentation of ZES can be less dramatic, and multiple ulcers in atypical locations that fail to respond to antacids should raise suspicion for ZES. The diagnosis of ZES is made by measuring the serum gastrin level, but patients must stop taking proton pump inhibitors for accurate testing. Other conditions can cause elevated gastrin levels, including pernicious anemia, treatment with proton pump inhibitors, renal failure, G-cell hyperplasia, atrophic gastritis, retained or excluded antrum, and gastric outlet obstruction. In equivocal cases, a secretin stimulation test may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of ZES.

Common symptoms include palpitations, trembling, diaphoresis, confusion or obtundation, and seizure, and family members may report that the patient has undergone a personality change.

Random blood sugar is 190 mg/dl. His older brother died of pancreatic cancer at age 58, and the patient is worried that he might also develop pancreatic cancer. Which of the following interventions would have the greatest impact on decreasing this patient's risk of pancreatic cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Achieve better glycemic control with insulin

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stop smoking Pancreatic cancer usually occurs after age 45 and is more common in men and African American patients. However, it is usually diagnosed relatively late in the disease course and has a high mortality rate. The major hereditary risk factors for pancreatic cancer include first-degree relatives with pancreatic cancer, hereditary pancreatitis, and germline mutations (eg, BRCA1, BRCA2, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome ). questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of yellow discoloration of the skin. He reports a loss of appetite. He lives with his wife and three children in a rural town where he works as a safety inspector at the local nuclear power plant. He is not physically active and his diet consists mostly of donuts and highly caloric processed food. He does not smoke but drinks 5 cans of beer daily. He is 182 cm tall and weighs 101 kg; his BMI is 30 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. There is a palpable, non-tender mass below the right costal margin. Scratch marks are seen on the extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Solution:

Possible etiologies include pancreatic head carcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma, and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Exposure to ionizing radiation (e.g., from working at a power plant) increases the risk of malignancy. Heavy alcohol consumption is a risk factor for HCC and pancreatic cancer, whereas obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma . Diagnostic evaluation should include liver function tests, parameters of cholestasis, and tumor markers (e.g., alpha-fetoprotein, CA 19-9, CEA).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe epigastric pain for a week. The pain is constant and he describes it as 6 out of 10 in intensity. The pain radiates to his back and is worse after meals. He has had several episodes of nausea and vomiting during this period. He has been hospitalized three times for severe abdominal pain in the past 3 years. He appears ill. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 87/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. There is severe epigastric tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Serum Glucose 96 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Amylase 150 U/L. A CT of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic enzyme therapy The patient has chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic enzyme therapy with orally administered enzyme preparations is recommended for the treatment of chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic enzymes improve the breakdown and absorption of food, resulting in weight gain and reduced stool frequency. This therapy also reduces the secretion of duodenal cholecystokinin, leading to decreased pancreatic stimulation and less pain. In addition, this patient should be counseled on lifestyle modifications regarding cessation of alcohol and smoking, consumption of small meals low in fat, and adequate hydration.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cancer antigen 19- 9 This patient most likely suffers from malignant biliary obstruction. Other less sensitive and specific laboratory findings that are elevated in pancreatic cancer include carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and, in some cases, lipase levels. Tumor markers should be obtained for the purpose of disease monitoring rather than for confirmation of the diagnosis. Higher levels of CA 19-9 at initial presentation are associated with a worse prognosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man reports weakness, sweating, tachycardia, confusion, and headache whenever he fasts for more than a few hours. He has prompt relief of symptoms when he eats. The physical exam reveals a BMI of 41 kg/m2 and a benign abdominal exam. Laboratory examination reveals an inappropriately high level of serum insulin during the episodes of fasting. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Diet modification to include frequent meals

questions.correct_answer: C. Simple excision of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simple excision of the tumor The patient’s presentation is classic for an These tumors are treated surgically, and simple excision of an adenoma is curative in the majority of cases. Seventy-five percent of these tumors are benign adenomas, and in 15% of affected patients, the adenomas are multiple. Tumors arise from the pancreatic β cells and result in elevated levels of insulin. Symptoms relate to a rapidly falling blood glucose level and are caused by epinephrine release triggered by hypoglycemia (sweating, weakness, tachycardia). Cerebral symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, convulsions, and coma are caused by glucose deprivation of the brain. Whipple triad summarizes the clinical findings in patients with insulinomas: (1) attacks precipitated by fasting or exertion, (2) fasting blood glucose concentrations below 50 mg/dL, and (3) symptoms relieved by oral or intravenous glucose administration.

options.label: D

questions.explanation:

Gemcitabine results in symptomatic improvement, improved pain control and performance status, and weight gain in patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer. However, survival is improved by only 1 to 2 months. Prior to gemcitabine, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) was used as the standard treatment for unresectable pancreatic cancer. questions.text: A 54-year-old man complains of intermittent jaundice associated with itching. This is associated with anorexia, weight loss, and upper abdominal discomfort. On examination, the patient is anemic, has scratch marks over his body, is slightly jaundiced, and has a gall bladder that is just palpable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Periampullary carcinoma This patient has intermittent obstructive jaundice (where the icterus waxes and wanes ) with a gall bladder that is minimally palpable. His anemia and weight loss should point to an underlying malignant lesion in the region of the lower end of the CBD. As the jaundice is intermittent, the diagnosis is obviously a periampullary carcinoma. In this condition, as the tumor grows, the patient’s jaundice gets deeper; as the carcinoma outgrows its blood supply, there is necrosis and sloughing of cancer, resulting in the alleviation of jaundice.
